abstract.p: Background: Neer and Foster’s open inferior capsular shift to treat acquired cases of anteroinferior shoulder instability due to an overstretched and redundant capsule is described with good results. Recently, new arthroscopic techniques were described to manage this problem.
Purpose: To assess the results of a new arthroscopic reinforced inferior capsular shift technique based on Neer and Foster’s open inferior capsular shift.
Study Design: Case series; Level of evidence, 4.

Methods: This new technique of arthroscopic inferior capsular shift was used to treat 108 patients with anteroinferior shoulder instability due to capsular redundancy as confirmed clinically and during arthroscopy. It reduces the size of the redundant capsular pouch and reinforces the thinned-out capsule. Intraoperatively, patients with associated labral tears (n = 25) and patients with open rotator intervals (n = 8) were excluded, and only 75 patients with pure capsular redundancy were included in this study.

Results: Patients were followed for a minimum of 7 years. All 75 patients had patulous and redundant capsules. Three patients (4.0%) had a redislocation after a significant trauma. The range of motion preoperatively was 168.1° ± 7.5° in forward elevation, 64.7° ± 7.9° in external rotation, and T5.0 ± T0.8 in internal rotation. Postoperatively, it was 167.2° ± 5.8° in forward elevation, 59.95° ± 4.9° in external rotation, and T7.1 ± T1.0 in internal rotation. The American Shoulder and Elbow Surgeons (ASES) (70.76 to 97.53; P < .001), Constant (90.02 to 99.24; P < .001), and University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA) (21.97 to 33.84; P < .001) scores demonstrated significant improvement postoperatively.

Conclusion: This novel technique of arthroscopic capsular shift addresses the problem of capsular redundancy present in many cases of anteroinferior shoulder instability. It tries to achieve a capsular shift based on the principles of Neer. The long-term results are very good.

body.p: Shoulder instability has a broad spectrum ranging from traces of instability to frank dislocation. According to Neer,24 anterior or anteroinferior instability may be traumatic, atraumatic, or acquired (caused by repeated microtrauma). The pathoanatomy differs in different types. In atraumatic cases, it is usually a capsular laxity, while in traumatic cases, it is the result of a labral tear (Bankart lesion).24

In traumatic cases, and with repeated dislocations, the labrum is usually frayed out, and the capsule becomes overstretched. Acquired cases are associated with an overstretched and redundant capsule due to excessive overhead activity or sports, with or without a labral tear. Such cases require a capsular repair.24

Many techniques of capsular repair have been described, but the most popular is the inferior capsular shift.25 Most of the arthroscopic techniques treating anterior shoulder instability deal with the labral tears and ignore the capsular problem.30,33

New arthroscopic capsular plication techniques have been described to manage this problem. They include transglenoid suture and multipleated plication stitches and other techniques.19,32,34 Arthroscopic thermal capsular shrinkage was also used to treat this condition with unsatisfactory outcomes (up to 37% recurrence),2,9 and it may be associated with some complications such as chondrolysis.17,36

An arthroscopic (L-type) inferior capsular shift technique was adopted by the senior author over 15 years ago and was published in 2004.11 This technique is a trial to achieve an inferior capsular shift based on the principles of Neer’s open inferior capsular shift.11 Neer’s procedure involves capsular detachment from the humeral neck and reattaching it to a more proximal site without medialization, thus obliterating the wide inferior axillary pouch without restricting external rotation.24

The purpose of this study was to assess the results of this new arthroscopic (L-type) inferior capsular shift technique in the past 12 years (between 1999 and 2003). We hypothesized that this technique would achieve as long-term good results as those achieved with Neer’s open capsular shift. Patients from the published 2004 study were not included in this study.

sec.title: Materials and Methods
sec.p: One hundred twenty-one consecutive patients underwent arthroscopic inferior capsular shift during the period between May 1999 and December 2003. Thirteen patients were lost to follow-up, and only 108 patients were available for the final follow-up. All patients gave their written consent to undergo this type of surgery. Also, we received the approval of our local ethical committee to undergo this retrospective study.

Of the 108 patients, 77 (71.29%) had a history of repetitive microtrauma due to excessive overhead activity or sports with no history of a recognizable major injury. The inclusion criteria of this retrospective study were the presence of capsular redundancy due to either an acquired type of anteroinferior shoulder instability or repeated traumatic instability with fraying of the labrum and overstretching of the capsule. Diagnosis was reached by history taking, clinical assessment, and magnetic resonance arthrography. The diagnosis was confirmed intraoperatively.

Intraoperatively, 25 patients of the original 108 (23.15%) had a labral tear (Bankart lesion), and another 8 patients (7.40%) had an open rotator interval.5 These patients were excluded from the study so that only cases with capsular redundancy were included. Accordingly, only 75 consecutive patients met the inclusion criteria. Forty-nine were male, while 26 were female. Fifty-two had instability in their right shoulder and 23 in their left shoulder. The dominant side was affected in 62 patients. The average age of the study group was 31.2 years, ranging from 16 to 49 years. All of the 75 patients received a trial of nonoperative treatment for at least 10 weeks that included rotator cuff coordinating and isometric strengthening exercises with no improvement.

All patients reported a history of recurrent shoulder dislocation (3-11 episodes) with a sensation of instability in the affected shoulder. During examination, 23 (30.66%) were found to have generalized ligamentous laxity. All patients had positive anterior apprehension test results with excessive anterior translation as compared with the contralateral shoulder. Fourteen patients (18.66%) showed a positive sulcus sign but with negative posterior apprehension test findings, indicating excessive inferior translation with a wide axillary pouch.15 Immediately preoperatively, the patients were examined under general anesthesia, and the degree of anterior translation was recorded and compared with that in the contralateral side. Of the 75 patients, 23 participated in sports, and 12 of these were professional athletes.

sec.title: Surgical Technique
sec.p: With the patient in the sitting position, an arthroscopic (L-type) inferior capsular shift (see the Video Supplement, available in the online version of this article at http://ajs.sagepub.com/supplemental/) was performed for all patients using a posterior portal for visualization and an anterior portal as a working portal. A 70° lens was used. A raw area with a rough surface was prepared along the capsular attachment to the humeral neck using a 3.5-mm abrader. This area was roughly 2 to 3 mm wide. This prepares a raw healing area for the edge of the flap that is to be later shifted (Figure 1 [Video scene 1]). An inverted L-shaped incision was performed in the inferior part of the anterior capsule using a radiofrequency or a laser probe (Figure 2 [Video scene 2]). One should avoid extending the vertical cut too far inferior into the axillary pouch to avoid injury of the axillary nerve.

sec.p: A straight (0°) chop needle pusher (Figure 3) with a No. 2 nonabsorbable suture was passed from outside into the apex of the triangular flap (Figure 4 [Video scene 3]). Then, a straight (0°) needle puller (Figure 3) was passed through the capsule overlying the horizontally oriented upper edge of the subscapularis to pull one of the 2 strands of the suture and bring it out of the anterior working portal (Figure 5 [Video scenes 4 and 5]). Next, the needle puller was passed once more via the anterior portal to pull the other strand of the suture directly through the anterior portal (Figure 6 [Video scenes 6 and 7]).

(A) Diagram of 0° chop needle puller used to pull the upper end of the suture out through the portal and through the upper edge of the subscapularis. (B) Intraoperative image of 0° chop needle puller used to pull the upper end of the suture out through the portal and through the upper edge of the subscapularis.
Retrieving the second strand of the suture.

sec.p: With the arm in the neutral position, the triangular flap was pulled up (Figure 7 [Video scene 8]), and the suture was tightened over the capsule overlying the upper border of the subscapularis using a sliding-knot technique, thus shifting the flap upward (Figure 8 [Video scene 9]). Usually (in 51 patients [68%]), another (second) suture was used to secure the shifted flap in position using the same method.

(B) Intraoperative image of the flap being shifted superiorly and laterally more than 10 mm toward the upper part of the subscapularis to lie on the prepared trough.

sec.title: Postoperative Management
sec.p: The arm was placed in a shoulder sling immobilizer for 6 weeks (in neutral position). Then, active range of motion and strengthening exercises were performed. After 12 weeks, the patients were allowed to return to normal daily activities. Sports were allowed only when the range of motion and the strength of forward elevation and external rotation were comparable with that of the opposite side. In most cases, this was achieved within 4 to 5 months postoperatively. After that, patients were examined every 3 months for the rest of the first year, every 4 months for the second year, and every 6 months for a further 2 years. Finally, patients were followed up on an annual basis.

The range of motion was determined by examination performed under general anesthesia immediately preoperatively and at the final follow-up. The patients were assessed preoperatively and postoperatively using the American Shoulder and Elbow Surgeons (ASES), Constant, and University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA) scoring systems.29 Statistical analysis of the results was done using a paired-sample t test and marginal homogeneity test.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The patients were followed up for a minimum of 7 years, ranging from 7 to 10.5 years. During the arthroscopic examination, all patients had an obvious wide axillary pouch indicating capsular redundancy. A positive “drive-through” sign was elicited in all patients. According to McFarland et al,22 this indicates the presence of laxity or redundancy.

All patients had a history of repetitive microtrauma due to excessive overhead activity or sports with no history of a recognizable major injury. Generalized ligamentous laxity was found in 23 (30.6%) patients. Ten patients had significant anterior pain while performing overhead activities, with a negative Neer impingement sign. Postoperatively, none of the patients complained of such pain. None of the patients had axillary nerve injury.

The ASES score demonstrated significant statistical improvement from 70.76 preoperatively to 97.53 postoperatively, with a significant improvement in both pain and activity (Table 1). According to the Constant score, there was a statistically significant improvement from 90.02 preoperatively to 99.24 postoperatively, with a significant improvement in pain, activity, and strength (Table 2). The UCLA score improved significantly from 21.97 preoperatively to 33.84 postoperatively, with a significant improvement in pain, function, active forward elevation, and patient satisfaction (Table 3).

sec.p: During the long period of follow-up, 3 patients (4.00%) suffered from a redislocation after a significant trauma. In one case, the arm of a volleyball player was caught in the net while falling. Another patient experienced an attack of seizures. One patient had an anterior dislocation as he held firmly to an overhead rail during sudden stoppage of a speeding underground. All 23 patients who participated in sports preoperatively were able to return to their preinjury level of sport activity.

The average range of motion was 168.1° ± 7.5° in forward elevation preoperatively and 167.2° ± 5.8° postoperatively. Preoperatively, external rotation was 64.7° ± 7.9° and 59.95° ± 4.9° postoperatively. Internal rotation reached up to T5.0 ± T0.8 preoperatively and T7.1 ± T1.0 postoperatively (Table 4).

sec.p: There was no significant statistical difference between the preoperative and postoperative ranges of motion with regard to forward elevation (P = .64). Regarding external rotation and internal rotation, the difference was statistically significant (P < .001 for external rotation; P < .001 for internal rotation), but this difference was of little clinical value during their daily or sport activities, as stated by the patients (Table 4).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Management of anteroinferior instability of the shoulder should be selected according to the preoperative clinical assessment and the pathological findings at the time of surgery.24 Bigliani and coworkers4 emphasized the importance of tailoring the amount of capsular shift to the degree of laxity or redundancy found. Cases of capsular redundancy, with or without labral tears,26 and cases caused by capsular redundancy or laxity alone, need capsular repair.1 Capsular repair reduces the capsular volume and reinforces the capsule, which is usually quite thin. Thus, it restores the capsuloligamentous tension without overconstraining the shoulder.6

Capsular repair may be achieved by anterior capsular tightening or by anteroinferior capsular shift. Anterior tightening adversely affects joint mechanics by decreasing joint stability, limiting both external rotation and arm elevation and requiring greater posterior joint forces to attain maximum elevation. The anteroinferior capsular shift improves joint stability while preserving external rotation, with no significant loss of maximum elevation.35 It yields a 90% or more satisfaction rate.6

Pollock and associates27 had less than 4% recurrence, while Cooper and Brems8 had 9% recurrence. Bigliani and coworkers4 had 2.9% recurrence in cases with bidirectional instability. Schneider and associates31 demonstrated that a 5-mm capsular shift was ineffective but that a 10-mm shift restored anterior and total anteroposterior translation to an almost normal status.

In our study, a shift of at least 10 mm was achieved intraoperatively. The lateral (humeral-based) capsular shift achieves more joint volume reduction than a medial (glenoid-based) shift and may be considered the preferred procedure for patients with excessive capsular redundancy.7,23 Taking that into consideration, we deduced that a laterally based arthroscopic capsular shift should be the best answer for capsular redundancy. This was the base for Neer and Foster’s capsular shift with its excellent results.25

Another method to reduce the widened capsule is thermal shrinkage. Open shift reduced intra-articular volume significantly more than arthroscopic thermal shrinkage.20 Many studies showed that a long follow-up of thermal shrinkage has a high rate of unsatisfactory results (reaching 37%).9,13 It may also be associated with some complications.17,36

Many of the arthroscopic techniques described for treating shoulder instability deal with the labral tears and ignore the capsular problem. That is probably the most crucial cause of recurrence of instability in cases managed arthroscopically.14 This may explain why when arthroscopic management of shoulder instability was first introduced in the late 1980s and early 1990s, the open Bankart procedure demonstrated good functional results, while the arthroscopic treatment without capsular shift showed a tendency toward more frequent and earlier recurrence of instability despite the better range of motion achieved.21 It may also be the reason why during the last decade, many studies aimed at developing arthroscopic techniques to treat the capsular problem.3,16,18,19,32

A recent cadaveric study revealed that in cases of capsular redundancy, 5 simple capsular plication stitches (whether suture anchors or suture only) result in a capsular volume reduction equivalent to an open lateral-based capsular shift.28 Technically, it is quite difficult to perform 5 simple capsular plication stitches; thus, a lateral-based capsular shift is a better answer to such a problem.

Recently, new arthroscopic capsular plication techniques have been described to achieve capsular volume reduction almost as much as the standard open capsular shift technique.19,32 Some studies were concerned with multidirectional cases. One of these studies used a transglenoid technique with a 12% recurrence rate.34 Another study used a modification of inferior capsular shift, among a limited number (only 10) of patients, with 10% recurrence.10 The disadvantage of both these studies is the short-term follow-up (2-3 years). Gartsman and colleagues12 performed arthroscopic repair for bidirectional cases with a 90% success rate. Sekiya et al32 used multipleated plication stitches, while Levy et al18 used a purse-string technique with a 5.4% recurrence rate. Unlike the technique we describe in our study, all of the other capsular repair techniques have not truly followed the basis of Neer’s capsular shift (humeral-side shift).

The technique we used in this study is one of those new arthroscopic capsular shift techniques. A disadvantage of this technique is that it is still a difficult technique that needs a highly experienced arthroscopic surgeon and requires a long learning curve. But at the same time, the very good long-term results achieved, with a minimal incidence of complications, are encouraging and in favor of this technique. There were no statistically significant limitations in the ranges of motion except for the external rotation and internal rotation (P < .001 for external rotation; P < .001 for internal rotation), but this difference was of little clinical value during their daily or sport activities, as stated by the patients (Table 4).

The strengths of our study include a substantial group of patients, the consistent technique, the length of follow-up, and the availability of preoperative and postoperative outcomes data. The major weakness is the retrospective design and the lack of a control group treated by another technique.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This novel technique of arthroscopic capsular shift addresses the problem of capsular redundancy present in many cases of anteroinferior shoulder instability. It tries to achieve a capsular shift based on the principles of Neer’s capsular shift. The long-term results are very good.
